p: Similar to the CMIP5 results (Fig. 3), the large sea-ice loss in the CESM1 1% CO 2 run also starts mainly during the summer–early winter season (Fig. 7a, b), and then extends to the winter–spring season (Fig. 7c) as the warming intensifies under increasing CO 2. Again, the sea-ice loss and other changes do not cause large AA during the summer months throughout the simulation (Figs. 6a, 7), whereas large AA is seen during the cold season when the releases of LW, SH, and LH fluxes into the Arctic air increase (Fig. 7a–c). The changes over a moving 40-year period (Fig. 7d) also show strong negative correlation (r = −0.87) between the local SIC change and the Arctic-global Tas difference, again suggesting a vital role of the sea-ice loss for AA.
